qas.question: What is one area where teleconferencing could not be used?
Who developed the first systems to transmit slow-scan video?
When was the first slow-scan video systems researched?
What was the bit rate of AT&T's Picturephone?
What was the bandwidth of AT&T's Picturephone?
Who developed the first system to transmit distance education?
In what area could business meetings not be used?

plausible_answers.text: due to the poor picture quality and the lack of efficient video compression techniques.

qas.question: Why did using business meetings to transmit slow-scan video fail?

plausible_answers.text: due to its high cost, but also due to a lack of network effect

qas.question: In the 1950's why did the Picturephone not become a success?
How many telephony networks were there in the world?

context: This technique was very expensive, though, and could not be used for applications such as <a0_0><b6_0>telemedicine<b6_0/><a0_0/>, distance education, and business meetings. Attempts at using normal telephony networks to transmit slow-scan video, such as the first systems developed by <a1_0><b5_0>AT&T Corporation<b5_0/><a1_0/>, first researched in <a2_0>the 1950s<a2_0/>, failed mostly <b7_0>due to the poor picture quality and the lack of efficient video compression techniques.<b7_0/> The greater <a4_0>1 MHz<a4_0/> bandwidth and <a3_0>6 Mbit/s<a3_0/> bit rate of the Picturephone in the 1970s also did not achieve commercial success, mostly <b8_0>due to its high cost, but also due to a lack of network effect<b8_0/> —with <b9_0>only a few hundred<b9_0/> Picturephones in the world, users had extremely few contacts they could actually call to, and interoperability with other videophone systems would not exist for decades.
